awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  How can we assess nitrogen saturation in xeric ecosystems? Accounting for water, time, and nitrogen availability
awd_abstract_narration:
Atmospheric nitrogen deposition has the potential to negatively affect ecosystems. It is usually clear if an ecosystem has received too much nitrogen because there are high levels of nitrogen in water and gas leaving the ecosystem. However, it is unclear how ecosystems in dry places, such as deserts, respond to added nitrogen. Drylands cover a third of Earth's land surface. It is important to understand how added nitrogen will affect these ecosystems. This project will also build the scientific workforce by training undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral associates in scientific methods. Many of these students will be reached through a Hispanic serving institution. Outreach activities to public K-12 schools will take place in southern California. This research will help predict how environmental change will affect ecosystem processes and services, such as clean air and water. This project will be especially important for understanding how dry ecosystems function. 
	
This project will evaluate nitrogen dynamics in watersheds receiving relatively little precipitation. The study sites are in southern California and receive different levels of atmospheric nitrogen deposition. The overall goal of the project is to develop a better framework for assessing nitrogen saturation. The research will expand nitrogen saturation theory to dry systems. It will account for the pulsed nature of rainfall during seasonal transitions. The project will quantify atmospheric nitrogen inputs using passive collectors and spatial modeling. Nitrogen measurements will also take place in the soil and water. These measurements will then be used to improve a biogeochemical model. The model will test watershed responses to nitrogen addition. The combined approaches of measurement and modeling in this study will advance theory surrounding the role of hydrology in driving nitrogen dynamics at the watershed scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined how global environmental changes affects biogeochemical cycling and water quality in dryland watersheds. Specifically, we focused on understanding the factors that govern nitrogen export to streams in regions with variable rainfall and intermittent drought. Our research had four main objectives: (1) to investigate how biogeochemical "hotspots"—small, relatively moist areas in the soil where nutrient cycling continues even as surrounding soils dry out—affect nitrogen cycling and its export to streams; (2) to examine how climate change and more variable rainfall patterns interact with these hotspots to either amplify or mitigate nitrogen export; (3) to assess how atmospheric nitrogen pollution and increasing rainfall variability influence long-term vegetation productivity, and its role in nitrogen retention and protecting water quality; and (4) to understand how wildfires, an integral component of drylands, might exacerbate global change threats to water quality. A key part of this work involved developing a new modeling tool to determine the nitrogen deposition threshold at which dryland watersheds become nitrogen-saturated and can no longer assimilate additional nitrogen, marking a critical threshold for ecosystem health and stream water quality.

The role of hotspots in driving nitrogen export: Dryland ecosystems experience periodic drying and wetting of soils, creating "hotspots" where nitrogen builds up during dry periods and is quickly flushed to streams when soils are rewetted. We developed a framework for representing hotspots using the coupled biogeochemical-ecohydrological model (RHESSys). We found that the abundance of hotspots, the moisture needed for subsurface flow from hotspots to reestablish, and the rate at which water diffuses out of them as soils dry out can all influence how much nitrogen accumulates and is released. We found that when hotspots were included in the RHESSys model, nitrogen export increased by 29%, helping us to more reliably predict nitrogen fluxes from dryland watersheds. 

How climate change and rainfall affect nitrogen dynamics: Using our new modeling framework, we examined how atmospheric nitrogen deposition and changes in rainfall patterns affect nitrogen export. We found that nitrogen losses, including export to streams and denitrification (where nitrogen is converted into gaseous forms and released into the atmosphere) are both sensitive to changes in rainfall timing. When watersheds are nitrogen-limited, the timing and variability of rainfall (such as long dry spells followed by heavy storms) can substantially increase nitrogen export to streams. In contrast, in nitrogen-saturated areas, denitrification is more sensitive to rainfall patterns. This suggests that as climate change leads to more intense and irregular rainfall events, dryland watersheds could face increased hydrologic and atmospheric nitrogen pollution.

How atmospheric nitrogen deposition and increasing rainfall variability influence decadal-scale vegetation productivity: Dryland plants play a crucial role in sequestering carbon and retaining nitrogen. However, plant productivity is threatened by increases in rainfall variability, which result in more frequent and extreme periods of drought and heavy rainfall. While much research has focused on how individual events like droughts affect plant growth, fewer studies have examined how changes in rainfall variability influence vegetation over longer (i.e., decadal) timescales. To address this gap, we applied our improved biogeochemical-ecohydrological modeling framework to two semiarid watersheds in the western United States. We investigated how rainfall variability and atmospheric nitrogen deposition influence plant growth and carbon sequestration. We found that although wet years can boost plant growth in the short term, they can also make plants more vulnerable to subsequent droughts. This can lead to higher plant mortality, increased carbon loss to the atmosphere, and greater nitrogen export into streams.

How rainfall variability & wildfire interact to drive biogeochemical cycling & water quality: Our findings illustrate how climate change, increases in rainfall variability, and atmospheric N deposition are threatening water quality in dryland watersheds—but how will they transform fuel conditions, wildfire behavior, and fire effects on nitrogen export? Once again using our improved modeling framework, we examined how rainfall variability and wildfire interact in dryland watersheds. We found that in unburned watersheds, nitrogen export to streams increases with increasing rainfall variability. After fire, the interaction between rainfall patterns and fire effects becomes even more complex. In wet years, higher rainfall variability can increase nitrogen export to streams, while in drier years, it may reduce it. Over the long term, however, high rainfall variability tends increase total nitrogen export because moisture extremes suppress plant growth and nitrogen uptake over the course of recovery, and plant productivity during wet years is not enough to offset the mortality that occurs in dry years.

Together, these studies illustrate how N export in chaparral watersheds will respond to future environmental change, including atmospheric N deposition, increases in the occurrence of large and severe fires, and more variable rainfall. They also suggest that as rainfall variability continues to increase, wildfire and nitrogen deposition will become even greater threats to water security.
